data.text: Contents
Information, Instruction and Training Requirements ............................................ 12
Introduction

This policy applies to the safe use of ionising and non-ionising radiations and is applicable to all staff who use or are involved in the use of ionising radiations or non-ionising radiations or radioactive substances within the Trust or who act as referrer, practitioner or operator for medical radiation exposures.
The Radiation Safety Policy has three aims:
To ensure as far as is reasonably practicable the radiation safety of employees, patients, members of the public, contractors and outside workers on its premises;

To keep radiation exposures as low as reasonably practicable and within limits [refer to Appendix 7] by having systems to ensure that the risks associated with the use of ionising and non-ionising radiation are well managed;
To ensure compliance with the requirements provided by legislation, codes of practice and guidance notes.
Achieve safe practices by ensuring that:
Risk to patients from exposure to radiation is low, compared to the benefit it produces [For laser refer to MHRA guidelines Appendix 5 and AOR2010 Appendix 6];
The radiation dose to staff is as low as reasonably practicable and within legal limits [refer to Appendix 7];
All employees have appropriate and on-going training and development.
Health and safety information arrangements will be shared with other Employers whose staff share the same workplaces;
‘Best Available Technique' (BAT) is employed to minimise the use and storage of activity radioactive material and radioactive waste generated.
Radioactive substances may be obtained only by prior permission of the Radioactive Waste Adviser in accordance with the procedures within this document (5.1);

If a staff member believes that significant radioactive contamination has occurred, a limit in the Environment Agency Permit has been breached or that radioactive material has or may have escaped or been lost, they shall report this without delay according to the Procedures within this document (6.1) and the Trust Incident Policy;
The Trust shall hold appropriate records of Notification, Registration and Consent, issued by the HSE, for all the Trust's work that involves ionising radiation;
The Trust shall hold appropriate permits, issued by the Environment Agency, for each site at which radioactive substances are kept or used;

The Trust shall also hold an appropriate license, issued by the Administration of Radioactive Substances Advisory Committee (ARSAC), for each site at which radioactive substances are to be administered to patients.
The Trust must provide a framework to ensure the above aims are met, and exercises this responsibility through the Chief Executive.
Scope

This policy applies to all employees (permanent, temporary, agency or locum) and contracted staff who work for the Trust or on Trust premises during the course of their employment and work with radiation (ionising such as x-rays, computed tomography, Positron Emission Tomography, unsealed sources, UVA/UVB, gamma radiation and non-ionising such as lasers and magnetic resonance).
The Policy applies to all premises under the management of the Trust that use either ionising or non-ionising radiation.
Definitions

table_items.text: Radiation from radioactive materials and x-ray, gamma ray and electron beam generating equipment that causes ionisation.

Radiation from laser, ultraviolet and Magnetic Resonance (MR) equipment. The term ‘non-ionising radiations' refers to artificial sources of electromagnetic radiation in the wavelength range 100 nm to 1 mm that are found by risk assessment to be potentially hazardous. Principally, these are optical radiations emitted by laser, ultraviolet and high intensity pulsed light sources.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities
[Refer to Appendix 9]
Radiation Protection Committee

The Trust has a radiation protection committee to ensure a radiation protection programme is implemented and reviewed, and to monitor radiation safety matters. This consists of senior members of the radiation protection groups and staff who attend the MSE radiology board meetings. The annual meeting will coincide with a MSE Radiology Board meeting.
4.1.1 The Radiation Protection Committee is responsible for:
Monitoring that the Trust fulfils all legal obligations relating to the safe use of ionising and non-ionising radiation;
Receiving an Annual report from the Radiation and Laser Protection Adviser, and once approved passing it to the Health and Safety Committees and thence to the board;
Formulating and reviewing a Radiation Safety Policy in the context of revised or new legislation, or because of changes in operational practice;
Making decisions on radiation protection matters that affect the Trust.
Radiation Protection Groups Each hospital (Broomfield, Basildon and Southend) has a radiation protection group
to ensure that the institution radiation protection programme is implemented and
reviewed, and to monitor radiation safety matters and to feed relevant information to
the radiation protection committee.
4.2.1 The Radiation Protection Group is responsible for
Monitoring that the institution fulfils all legal obligations relating to the safe use of ionising and non-ionising radiation including;
Ensuring local rules are kept up to date;
Ensuring risk assessments are kept up to date;
Investigation of incidents or accidents relating to the use of radiation.
The Health and Safety Group (HSG) The HSG will act and be recognised for all statutory and regulatory purposes as the
Group responsible for Health and Safety within the Trust and shall scrutinise or
investigate any areas covered within its Terms of Reference.
Chief Executive has ultimate responsibility for compliance with legislation for the use of radiation within the Trust, and ensuring the safe practices as specified in the introduction.
Heads of Departments/Line Managers Managers are responsible for radiation safety within their departments. This includes:
Preparing and maintaining written risk assessments regarding this work;
Ensuring all radiation equipment is installed, critically examined, commissioned, maintained and subject to a suitable QA programme.
Restricting exposure to ionising radiation to ALARP and within limits;
Appointing suitable and sufficient RPS / LPSs are appointed in writing [Appendix 2 and 4];
Ensuring Procedures and Protocols for Medical Exposures are in place for all diagnostic and therapeutic uses of radiation or radioactive substances undertaken in their Department;
Ensuring referrers, practitioners or operators who are appropriately qualified, trained and follow the Trust Procedures for Medical Exposures;
Ensure up to date local rules are in place, and made available to staff;
Ensuring the equipment inventory is maintained and reviewed;
Ensuring their staff are adequately trained to carry out their duties, or provided with appropriate information;

Ensure staff members and other persons within a class specified in Schedule 3 of the IRR2017 are not exposed to radiation to exceed any dose limit specified in part 2 of that schedule [refer to appendix 7];
Ensuring staff issued with radiation monitoring badges wear their badges correctly (type, frequency and position);
Managing, reviewing and where necessary, acting on results from radiation monitoring;
Ensuring suitable and sufficient PPE is provided;
Ensuring adequate facilities are provided for storage of the PPE;
Ensure PPE checked visually / screened for damage on a regular basis and at least once annually, and record condition / defects;
Liaise with the Trust's Radiation Permit Manager wherever radioactive sources or radioactive materials are used or stored, to ensure that the activities are covered by the Trust's permit;
Liaising with the Trust's DGSA whenever arrangements need to be put in place for transport of radioactive materials;
Ensuring medical exposures for research purposes may only be undertaken with the approval of the appropriate Research Ethics Committee, acting on the
advice of a MPE;
Liaise as appropriate with the RPA, RWA, MPE and LPA, in all aspects of radiation safety; including equipment purchase [see Appendix 1];

If an employee is likely to receive an effective dose greater than 6mSv per year or an equivalent dose greater than 15mSv for the lens of the eye or 150mSv per year for the skin or extremities designate that employee as a classified worker and immediately inform them of this [see Appendix 7];

The manager must ensure they understand the arrangements for the control of radioactive substances, articles and equipment as listed under part 6 of the IRR2017 and within Schedule 23 of EPR16 [see Appendix  for unsealed sources];
Ensure all staff working with ionising radiation understand their duties under part 7 of the IRR2017;

(If relevant) Ensuring that they have procedures for the control of Radioactive Substances as well as departmental local rules and standard operating procedures in place for the effective control of radioactive substances and radioactive waste (see section 5.1) and Appendix  This includes ensuring:

4.5.1  All staff involved in exposing patients must ensure they know and follow the written policies as specified in IR(ME)R17 schedule 2, and have adequate training as specified in schedule 3. This legislation is detailed in a separate document (s) [see Appendix 3].
Radiation and Laser Protection Adviser (RPA / LPA)
A RPA must be appointed to advise on the use of ionising radiation;
A LPA must be appointed if class 3R, 3B or 4 lasers are used;
Advising the Trust and its employees on all matters concerning the use of ionising and non-ionising radiation, in particular on compliance with statutory requirements;
Maintaining an up-to-date knowledge of the properties and hazards of the ionising and non-ionising radiations used by the Trust and provide advice on risk assessments, local rules;
Submitting an annual written report to the Radiation Protection Committee;
Maintaining a current certificate of competence from an assessing body recognised under IRR2017;
Fulfilling the duties of a RPA as detailed in the IRR17.
Radioactive Waste Adviser
Responsible for advising the Trust and its employees on all matters regarding radioactive waste;
Maintaining a current certificate of competence from an assessing body recognised under IRR2017;
Fulfilling the duties of a RWA as detailed in the IRR17.
Radiation and Laser Protection Supervisors

4.8.1 A suitable RPS / LPS should be available whenever work with ionising radiation is undertaken, with sufficient numbers to be available whenever work with ionising radiation or class 3R, 3B or 4 lasers is undertaken [refer to Appendix 2 and 4].
4.8.2 Their primary role is to supervise work to ensure that it carried out in accordance with the local rules for laser / radiation safety and other duties as listed in the IRR17.
Medical Physics Experts For ionising radiation the Trust is required to appoint suitable “medical physics
experts” to provide advice regarding optimisation of patient radiation doses and
quality assurance relating to medical radiation exposures as detailed under
IR(ME)R2017. They must also be consulted on equipment purchases relating to the
use of radiation [refer to Appendix 1].
IRMER Practitioners

4.10.1 Wherever patients are exposed to ionising radiation for medical purposes (including research and non-medical imaging purposes), heads of department must appoint IRMER Practitioners to justify the use of this radiation.

4.10.2 Every referral for a medical exposure must be individually checked by an IRMER Practitioner, prior to patient exposure, to judge whether or not sufficient net benefit can be expected from the radiation. This task may be delegated, but responsibility remains with the IRMER Practitioner. Arrangements for delegation must be in writing and must indicate how the IRMER Practitioner is identified for each medical radiation exposure.

4.10.3 If the radiation exposure involves administration of a radioactive material, then the IRMER practitioner responsible for checking the clinical referral must hold a relevant, up-to-date ARSAC licence.
Referring Practitioners Whenever a patient is referred for a medical exposure, the referrer must provide the
IRMER Practitioner with sufficient medical data to enable the IRMER Practitioner to
decide whether or not sufficient net benefit can be expected from the radiation
exposure.
Dangerous Goods Safety Adviser A Dangerous Goods Safety Adviser must be appointed to provide advice regarding transport of radioactive materials, and must meet relevant staff at least annually.
Radiation Permit Manager The radiation permit manager liaises with the Environment Agency whenever
changes are needed to any of the following permits held by the Trust:
Permit to keep and use a limited number of sealed radioactive sources;
Permit to keep and use limited quantities of unsealed radioactive substances;
Permit to accumulate limited amounts of radioactive waste;
Permit to dispose of limited amounts of radioactive waste.
4.13.1 The Radiation Permit Manager prepares annual summaries for the entire Trust showing the rate of disposal of radioactive waste, and submits these to the Environment Agency.
4.13.2 The Radiation Permit Manager reports to the Radiation Protection Groups and Committee.
Occupational Health Department Line management will liaise with the RPA and the occupational health department
with regard to the monitoring of staff in receipt of higher than expected radiation
exposure, and in addition with reference to the Health Protection Agency if
appropriate.
Employees Members of staff may carry out radiation work only if it is outlined within their written
job description, provided by their manager. Members of staff must:
Maintain knowledge of local rules, written systems of work (including the relevant IRMER policies in Appendix 3) and the practical precautions needed to carry out their work and abide by them;
Only operate radiation equipment or work with radioactive substances if appropriately qualified, trained and authorised to do so;
Keep their and others radiation exposure ALARP;

Report equipment / procedure issues, any accidental or unintended exposure or “near miss” involving radiation to their Head of Department, line manager or their RPS. If a SAUE or CSAUE occurs (or is suspected), after investigation this may be reportable to the CQC;
If PPE is provided must:
If you expose patients to ionising radiation understand your duties under IR(ME)R [see Appendix 3];
Practitioners administering radiopharmaceuticals or sealed radioactive sources shall hold an appropriate license from ARSAC;
Staff cannot use radioactive substances until suitably trained and authorised (after receiving local training in the departmental operating procedures from

the clinical lead) [refer to Appendix 10];   Staff working with radioactive substances shall be trained to deal with minor and major levels of radioactive contamination;   Staff not directly involved in the use of radioactive substances (for example domestic, security, porters and clerical staff) shall be given sufficient information and instruction by the Manager / RPS so that they may work safely in the departments (Nuclear Medicine and Radiotherapy) without affecting the safe management of radioactive substances.
Magnetic Resonance Safety Expert (MRSE) Provision of advice on the engineering and scientific aspects of the safe clinical use
of Magnetic Resonance (MR) [See Appendix 9 for the Trust management structure]
Main procedural document points (process)
Managers have responsibility for radiation safety in their particular areas and with the support provided by identified individuals in specific support roles this will;
Ensure the radiation safety of employees, patients, members of the public, contractors and outside workers on its premises;
Ensure compliance with the requirements provided by legislation, codes of practice and guidance notes.
Achieve safe practices by ensuring that:
The risk to patients resulting from exposure to radiation is low, compared to the benefit it produces;
The radiation dose to staff is as low as reasonably practicable;
All employees are appropriately trained and undergo relevant continuous training and development.
Information, instruction and training requirements
All staff working with radiation must have appropriate training in radiation safety (ionising or non-ionising). For laser users this includes core of knowledge.
Staff who operate equipment must be able to show evidence of competency / training.
Staff working under IRMER must have sufficient education and training to fulfil their roles.
Staff associated with the work must have access to appropriate information.
Staff should attend refresher training regularly (recommended as every 2-3 years).
Monitoring compliance
The Radiology Governance Lead will review all risk events. Any immediate training or educational issues relating to the lack of compliance with this guideline will be addressed on a one to one basis.
A quarterly audit of compliance will be undertaken by reviewing all risk events related to the operation of this guideline. This audit will form part of the RPG agenda.
All incidents and any trend analysis will be reviewed at the Radiology audit and the RPC.
The RPG will report to the HSG on a quarterly basis and submit an annual report to the HSG.

This policy must be approved and implemented by the RPC (following approval local RPG), the Health and Safety Committee of the Trust (and the local H&S committee) and the Imaging Governance Committee for each institution.
Once ratified by the Joint Document Management Group the author will be notified.
Communication
The policy will be uploaded the Intranet by Document Control.
The author is responsible for ensuring that clinical staff are directly informed via attendance at meetings or by direct email.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust aim to design and implement services, policies, procedures, needs of our service, population and workforce, ensuring that no person is placed at a disadvantage over others.
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and
meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 1).

Appendix 5: MHRA guidelines for the safe use of lasers
The Trust will ensure that wherever lasers are used ownership is clearly established and risks to patients, staff and others are adequately controlled

All laser systems in use should conform to the requirements of current standards and guidance. Detailed arrangements for complying with the guidance are set out in departmental Local Rules for Laser Protection for Class 3R, 3B and 4 lasers.
Managers are responsible for ensuring that

all sources of laser radiation exposure are properly identified and that appropriate risk assessments are carried out and reviewed on a regular basis or when any alterations are made to staff, environment or equipment.
laser controlled areas are designated and the necessary control measures are in place to provide adequate protection from laser radiation and associated hazards.
any necessary PPE is provided, worn and maintained as appropriate.
all lasers have a regular maintenance contract.
contingency plans are in the local rules for any foreseeable laser incident.
MEMS are consulted before the purchase or loan of new laser equipment. Procedures should be in place for providing risk assessments of new or loaned lasers and the LPA must be alerted.
no personnel must use a laser unless they are suitably qualified, trained and have been authorised to act as clinical laser operators
in the event of an incident involving laser radiation a Trust incident form is completed
When carrying out all the above duties, managers are expected to seek advice and assistance, as appropriate, from the LPS, LPA, and the Radiation Protection Committee.
Laser Protection Supervisor – required for each laser of class 3R, 3B or
A register of authorised users should be maintained by the Laser Protection Supervisor.
The LPS is responsible for supervising the overall safety of the laser environment but the clinician carrying out the procedure remains responsible for the safety of the patient. Duties include
Ensuring the local rules are followed, and letting the LPA know if amendment required.
Ensuring that the register of Authorised Users is maintained and correct authorisation procedure followed.
To obtain written statements from each Authorised Users that they have read and understood the Local Rules and send copies of statements to the LPA.
To ensure that only Authorised Users operate the laser.
To inform the LPA as soon as possible as possible in the event of an incident occurring.
To seek assistance from the LPA on the safety implication when a change in operating procedure is envisaged.
Laser Protection Supervisors should be familiar with the ‘Core of Knowledge' for laser safety and be able to provide evidence of suitable training.
Authorised Users
Class 3R, 3B and 4 lasers should only be used by an authorised user who must appear on
the register of authorised users.
Appendix 6: Control of artificial optical radiation at work
Artificial Optical Radiation (AOR) is defined as radiation in the wavelength range 100nm - 1mm.
Lasers are already dealt with under the requirements of the MHRA guidelines; the vast majority of other light sources are known to be safe.
Any hazardous sources are identified by the LPA from the risk assessments carried out under the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 and amendments.
In this event the following measures need to be considered:-
Restrict access to hazardous areas to trained, authorised personnel only
Controlling access by engineering controls and design features of equipment
Increase distance between staff and harmful source
Minimise time of exposure
Issue PPE
Ensure safe systems of work are in place and that workers involved have received suitable and sufficient information and training
Have documented risk assessments
Have a procedure for effectively dealing with accidents

Appendix 10: Procedures for working with unsealed sources
Process for managing radioactive substances 10.1.  Nuclear Medicine Facilities - Broomfield

10.1.1 The Nuclear Medicine Department at Broomfield Hospital has lockable rooms for dispensing, patient administration, two gamma cameras, a patient toilet and stores for radioactive sources and waste.
10.1.2 There is a self-contained and purpose built radioactive waste store.
10.1.3 Radiopharmaceuticals are purchased in multi-dose vials.
10.1.4 Sentinel node biopsies are undertaken in the Operating Theatres which have adequate facilities for the safe use of the low level of radioactivity involved.
Nuclear Medicine Facilities - Basildon
10.2.1 The Nuclear Medicine Department at Basildon Hospital has lockable rooms for dispensing, patient administration, one gamma camera, a patient toilet and stores for radioactive sources and waste.
10.2.2 There is a self-contained and purpose built radioactive waste store.
10.2.3 Radiopharmaceuticals are purchased in multi-dose vials.
10.2.4 Sentinel node biopsies are undertaken in the Operating Theatres which have adequate facilities for the safe use of the low level of radioactivity involved.
Nuclear Medicine Facilities - Southend

10.3.1 The Nuclear Medicine Department at Southend Hospital has lockable rooms for dispensing, patient administration, two gamma cameras, a patient toilet and stores for radioactive sources and waste.
10.3.2 There is a self-contained radioactive waste store.
10.3.3 Radiopharmaceuticals are purchased in multi-dose vials.
10.3.4 Sentinel node biopsies are undertaken in the Operating Theatres which have adequate facilities for the safe use of the low level of radioactivity involved.
Management of Radioactive Substances and the Procurement, Operation and Maintenance of Equipment and Systems
10.4.1.  Standard operating procedures shall be written as follows:

To set down the instructions for ordering, receipt, storage, use and disposal of radioactive substances such that they are controlled in accordance with the conditions of the Environment Agency permits.

To set down the instructions for the procurement, operation and maintenance of any equipment and systems associated with the use of radioactive substances and the management of radioactive waste. Equipment shall be maintained in accordance with manufacturer recommendations.
To set down the instructions for all the clinical procedures which involve the use of radioactive substances.
Radioactive sources and radioactive waste
The Department clinical lead/RPS and the RWA or the RPA (through the Southend Hospital switchboard) must be notified directly without delay in the event of any of the following:
any malfunction, breakdown or failure of equipment, techniques or accident which caused or may cause a source to be damaged or lost
any malfunction, breakdown or failure of equipment, techniques or accident which caused, is causing or may cause significant pollution or may generate significant amounts of radioactive waste
any breach of a limit specified in a permit
any escape of accumulated radioactive waste
loss or theft or suspected loss or theft of radioactive material or radioactive waste

The RWA / RPA shall notify the Environment Agency if required through the Incident Hotline on 0800 80 70 60 (24 hours) stating that radioactivity is involved so that the call is directed to the nuclear duty clinical lead.

In the event of the loss or suspected loss or the theft or attempted theft of radioactive material or radioactive waste, the RWA / RPA shall inform the Police on 0800 789 321 (24 hours) stating that this is an incident involving a radioactive source.
Radioactive substances records and compliance with permit limits
10.6.1 Records of the receipt and use of radioactive sources and of the receipt, accumulation and disposal of radioactive waste are maintained locally by each Department.

10.6.2 Compliance with permit limits and conditions shall be achieved through the ongoing assessment of records, the vigilance of the RPS and through regular RWA audits. An annual pollution inventory shall be sent to the Environment Agency by the RWA. A standard operating procedure on record-keeping shall be set down that includes the action to be taken in the event of a permit condition being breached and the time for which records shall be retained.
Application of Best Available Techniques (BAT)
10.7.1 The Trust applies best available techniques (BAT):
to minimise the activity of radioactive material kept or used on the premises,
to minimise the activity of radioactive waste produced, the period for which it is accumulated, and the activity and volume of all disposals and
to dispose of radioactive waste at times, in a form, and in a manner so as to minimise the radiological effects on the environment and members of the public.

Justification: In the Nuclear Medicine departments, requests for routine scans are authorised by operators under written procedures. All other requests are justified by consultants who will consider any appropriate alternatives, and if necessary arrange for such, before authorising those requests that are appropriate in accordance with their ARSAC (Administration of Radioactive Substances Advisory Committee) licence.
Any new use of radioactivity shall be planned in advance through discussion with the Head of the Department and the RPS. The Department is required to consider and record the following:
justify the use of radioactive materials for the work being planned,
consider whether the amounts of radioactivity being used could be reduced,
consider whether alternative methods, or lower radioactivity could be used,
estimate the activity of the radionuclide which will be used, the maximum stock needed and the amounts and types of radioactive waste generated

undertake a risk assessment and associated contingency plan which demonstrate a commitment to minimising the use of each specified radionuclide/ radiopharmaceutical, and the consequent generation of all forms of waste.  This shall then be reviewed in conjunction with the RWA who shall also provide a
written assessment of the impact on permit limits and conditions.

Purchase and control of stock: Only the RPS or other authorised persons shall purchase radioactive stock. All stock is delivered to the Nuclear Medicine Department or radiotherapy and securely stored. Details of the stock such as radionuclide, activity and date received are recorded. The stock is kept in a suitable container in a designated room.

Personal and area contamination monitoring:  Each department has systems and equipment in place for performing and recording results of area and personal contamination monitoring. These records are checked at annual audits by the RWA and on an ad-hoc basis.
Proportionality

The majority of the radioactive waste produced is in the form of aqueous waste following patient investigations in the Nuclear Medicine departments. Where possible, solid waste is decayed to background and disposed of as non-active clinical waste (see Worker Dose below).

Aqueous waste disposal is subject to radiological assessment when variations to the permits are sought and doses to critical groups are assessed and considered against guidance available from regulatory and advisory bodies.

Aqueous waste: In each Nuclear Medicine Department, the activity deemed to have been discharged into the sewerage system is calculated each month from the total activity administered to the patients using the percentage waste figures accepted by the Environment Agency. Each month, disposals are checked against the permit to ensure that permitted limits are not approached or exceeded. These figures are also used in the annual return of the Pollution Inventory to the Environment Agency.

Solid Waste: Solid waste arises as the activity remaining in vials after patient administrations and from the low-level solid waste arising from syringes, needles, gloves etc. Each Department keeps records of all accumulation and disposals.

Storage of Radioactive Waste: Waste is segregated into short and long half-life containers. Short-lived waste is monitored weekly and disposed of if it has decayed to background. Longer-lived waste is transferred to the Waste Store where it may be held for longer periods, depending on permits issued by the Environment Agency.
Decision between Options

For the majority of radioactive waste arising there is no scope to consider alternative options. The basic culture of waste disposal used by the Trust is to reduce environmental impact. In the case of radioactive substances, this is translated into as an intention to utilise decay-storage where possible. This reduces environmental impact and is a cost effective strategy for the Trust.
BAT Review
10.16.1 BAT is a culture and as such is not subject to specific review. Procedures,
processes and management arrangements which impact on BAT are reviewed annually by the RWA.

10.16.2 Records of waste disposal are reviewed regularly by the RPS and other scientific staff. The Department is audited annually by the RWA and issues relating to BAT are discussed as part of this review.
10.16.3 Changes in medical practice, for example the development of a novel procedure using radioactive substances, also provide an opportunity for BAT review through radiological impact assessment.
Impact on Critical Groups

The measure of success for the BAT strategies employed by Trust is their impact on critical groups. These are assessed when any changes in waste disposal are proposed. The Trust aim is to keep such impacts ALARP.
Worker Dose
10.18.1 The most significant issue for BAT that the Trust faces is balancing environmental impact with doses to nuclear medicine staff.

10.18.3 Staff are monitored for their exposure to ionising radiation and the results of this monitoring show, as for staff in all nuclear medicine departments, that extremity doses are the issue of greatest concern. However, through the principles applied above, staff keep their doses as low as reasonably practicable.
10.18.4 Options for disposal of residue are through the aqueous or solid waste streams. The former requires an operator to extract the residue from the vial, usually through
a syringe, and thence into a designated sink. This will increase the operator
extremity dose. It also carries some risk of contamination.

10.18.4 An alternative is to declare the residue as solid waste, i.e. liquid within a solid vial. Decay storage would subsequently allow a reduced activity of waste to be disposed of. As most of the radionuclides used are short-lived, decay is relatively rapid and certainly within the permitted decay storage limits. Taking into account the concept
of proportionality, this route is adopted by the Trust as it represents the least risk to staff.

A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
The proposal is to move towards one radiation safety policy across the MSE, to replace the site- specific policies.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
(1) To more easily keep the policy up-to-date (2) To make it easier for staff working with radiation to transfer between MSE sites (3) To ensure staff follow the same policy at each site
Who benefits from this change and how?
Staff and Patients will benefit – this policy is for staff and patient radiation safety
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
No – this consolidates and updates documents that are already in place.
